titleStmt.title: Linköping Diocesan Library, Kl f 3
titleStmt.sponsor: Greek manuscripts in Sweden – a digitization and cataloguing project

publicationStmt.publisher: manuscripta.se: A Digital Catalogue of Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts in Sweden

supportDesc.foliation: Contemporary pagination and foliation in brown ink, probably in Erik Benzelius the Younger’s hand and presenting different sequences for each unit. At the end of the MS it has been complemented in pencil by a later hand: pages 1–24, folios 33–42, folios 1–32, folios 1a–15a, pages 1b–7b

p.note: A label for Linköping Diocesan Library.
Erik Benzelius the Younger’s signature in brown ink.

binding.p: Sewn on three flat sewing supports. Limp covers made out of blue paper glued onto printed waste, cut flush with the bookblock. No endleaf at the end of the volume. Flat spine later covered with a strip of shiny, brown marbled paper, horizontal gilt fillets, and a beige paper label with gold-tooled title (Andronici Epist. Graece). Edges sprinkled in red.

provenance.p: Brought home to Uppsala and then in to Linköping as he was appointed Bishop of that diocese.

acquisition.p: Part of Erik Benzelius the Younger’s donation to Linköping Diocesan Library.

msItem.title: Epistula ad Georgius Palaeologus Dishypatus
msItem.rubric: Ἀνδρονίκου τοῦ Καλλίστου εἰς τὸν μεγαλοπρεπῆ ἄνδρα κύριον Γεώργιον Παλαιολόγον τὸν δυσύπατον
msItem.incipit: Μεγαλοπρεπὲς ἄνερ εἴης μοι ὑγιαίνων Θεοῦ βοηθεία ὑγιαινοντι καὶ αὐτῷ
msItem.explicit: ποιήσαι τὴν μεγαλοπρεπείαν σοῦ εὐδαίμονα. ἐν Λουδονία μουνυχιῶνος γ´ ἱσταμένου.

note.p: In PG the letter is dated A.D. Martii mensis 1476.

There are two notes in Latin in the upper margin of , partly trimmed. On the left: ... cod. fol. .... The longer note on the right gives more information: exstat haec epistula in ... 2211, ipsius credo Hermonym... descripta eoque suspecta. (verba sunt domini Boivinii). Extat item in codice Colbertino 3028, pag. 1. These two mss (with the present shelfmarks Paris. gr. 2966 and Paris. gr. 3043 respectively) do have the Andronicus letter as their first text. It is catalogued as 16th cent. but could well be 17th.
Paris. gr. 2966, i.e. Medic.-Reg. 2211, has the same indent for the initial in the first paragraph also without filling it in. Cf. also Monacensis gr. 265, fol. 33v–36r, 16th cent.

msItem.title: Epistula Ad Demetrius Sguropulus
msItem.incipit: Θεόδωρος Δημητρίω εὖ πράττειν. δεινὰ πάλιν ἀπαγγέλεις,
msItem.explicit: χαλεπωτέραν καθίστησιν. ἔρρωσο ἀπὸ Ῥώμης ἰουνίου ιηʹ.

note.p: Probably copied from Paris. gr. 2966, fol. 1v–2v.

For the additional information on who the addressée is, see Leone’s edition. He also gives a fuller dating of the letter, namely 18. June 1473. In PG the adressée is interpreted as Demetrios Chalkondyles.

msItem.title: Epistula ad Bessarion
msItem.note: Probably copied from Paris. gr. 2966, fol. 2v–4r. This means that the first three epistles of our manuscript are identical with, and come in the same order, in this Paris ms. The same is true with Paris. gr. 3043, but since the following two texts are present only in the aforementioned, it increases the likelihood that Paris. gr. 2966 is the protograph of our ms. Furthermore, the wording of the marginal note on in our ms seems to strengthen this surmise. Another clue pointing in the same direction is the marginal note on the first page of Paris. gr. 2966, where Paris. gr. 2131 is mentioned. That is namely in all likelihood the protograph to another text in our ms (); more on this below. (Note that these conclusions are based mainly on internal evidence in the mss – we have not collated the texts in detail.)

msItem.title: Epistula ad Marcus Musurus
msItem.explicit: φιλεῖν ἤδη καὶ οὗτος ἄρχεται. ἔρρωσο.

msItem.title: Responsa ad quaestiones Bessarion
msItem.rubric: Πλήθωνος πρὸς τὰς παρὰ τοῦ Βησσαρίωνος κατ᾽αὐτοῦ ἀντιλείψεις
msItem.incipit: Πρὸς τ᾽ἄλλα σου οὐδὲν ἐμὲ δεῖ λέγειν
msItem.note: The text was copied from Paris. gr. 2966, fol. 5r (14 ll.). A note in the lower marg. of describes the contents of Par. gr. 2966: Ex regia Parisiensi Bibliotheca. cod. mss. graec. 2211. annotatio domini du Cange in frontispiciis haec est: Andronici Callisti, Theodori Gazae, Georgii Amiratzae, Demetrii et Plethonis epistolae aliquot, post tempora concilii florentini scriptae. The note is still there in the Paris ms.

msItem.title: Epistula Ad Demetrios Chalkondyles
msItem.rubric: Epistola Theodori [Gazae fortasse ad Demetr. Chalkondylam]
msItem.incipit: Ἐκομίσθη μοὶ ἡ ἐπιστολὴ, ἥν τὰ μὲν μενφόμενος
msItem.explicit: καὶ σὲ φιλεῖν ἤδη καὶ οὗτος ἄρχεται. ἔρρωσο.

note.p: In the left of the upper marg. at , a note says vid. cod. Reg. 2211. fol. 1.. The same reference is present in Paris. gr. 2131, fol. 173v (i.e., on the page opposing the Theodorus letter, which starts on fol. 174r vide cod. 2211. fol.o 1.o. v.o ); it seems likely that our scribe took it more or less verbatim directly from Paris. 2131 (olim Paris. 3516). The reference points to the aforementioned letter from Theodorus to Demetrius – the one we have on . On fol. 1v in Paris. 2211, there is a corresponding cross reference to Codicem 3516. fol.o 174.

On there is another note: NB Epistola haec, quemadmodum totus fere codex 2211 Reg. Par. Biblioteca, exarata est manu Marci Musuri cuius fuit codex, ille ipse, adquem in superioribus Demetrii epistola fuit scripta. vid. pag. 12. The current shelfmark of codex 2211 is Par. gr. 2966, the scribe of which ms was Georgius Hermonymus, as is also the opinion of our scribe in the marginal note on . Thus, it is not quite clear what our scribe means with the wording quemadmodum totus fere codex 2211, since that codex does not include the letter at issue here. Paris. gr. 2131, fol. 174v–183v, are in the hand of Marcus Musurus. The note on makes this clear; it also gives the cross reference to Marcus Musurus being the adressée on .
The small lacuna on (τῶν λεγομένων τε καὶ ὑπονοουμένων εὑρίσκῃ) is present also in Paris. 2131.
Pietro Luigi M. Leone does not itemize the addressée as Demetrios Chalkondyles, but he does give a date and place for the letter: Demetrio, Ferrariam Romae, m. Mart. 1450 .

msItem.title: Ep. 49, ad Michael Apostolis
msItem.rubric: Βησσαρίων καρδινάλις ὁ κύριος Νικαίας, Μιχαήλῳ τῷ Ἀποστόλῃ Βυζαντίῳ χαίρειν
msItem.note: This letter is transmitted in many mss, among which see also Upsal. gr. 8, fol. 163v–167v. A note next to the title indicates: Spar. no. 49 p. 163, thus referring to that ms, which belonged to Johan Gabriel Sparwenfeldt.

watermark.note: Main watermark, passim. It is accompanied by letters in a frame forming a long name, in the same manner as in the aforementioned examples but difficult to decipher.
This Coat of Arms has a crown surmounted by a small fleur-de-lis.

A shorter name, or combination of characters, but inside the same kind of frame as the name previously mentioned; probably 4–5 characters long, the second? character being an elongated I with a hook. Several appearances throughout the volume.
Another combination of a limited number of characters; this time one can discern a fleur-de-lis, and probably an oval of the same height as the hook. A few appearances.

collation.formula: Q1–33.IIp.24 + Q12–143.IIf.33–f.42 + Q4–118.IIf.1–f.32 + Q15–173.IIf.12a + Q18(I + 1f.f.13a)f.15a: the singulion pasted onto the following quire, and the stub from the single leaf probably stuck in-between + Q19IIf.8b
collation.signatures: In the lower left margin of first recto in all quires except for the last one, in different character series for each codicological unit: Q1–3: A–C, Q4–14: a–l, Q15–17: α–δ, Q19: none.
collation.catchwords: In the lower right margin of last verso in Q4–14, i.e. only in codicological unit 2.

decoDesc.p: No decorations. There is a blank space for a larger initial on , but it was never filled in. Rubrics written in same ink as the texts.

origin.p:
Copies in Erik Benzelius the Younger’s hand from manuscripts at Paris
Bibliothèque nationale de France, created in the year 1700 as Erik Benzelius the Younger paid a visit there during his Grand Tour. Several earlier copyists are mentioned by Erik Benzelius the Younger, among them Marcus Musurus.

revisionDesc.change: Changing status from draft to published
